subject: RE: [junit] Looking for some "Best Practices"
msgSnippet: ... I ve only got one chance to start off with good practices, and I d better get it right. But others have pointed me toward tools for doing this. *
messageBody:
> >QUESTION 2:
> > How do I automatically build the suite of all tests?
> I recommend starting by creating the suites manually to get a feel for
> composable tests. Then seek the power of Ant.

I've only got one chance to start off with good practices, and
I'd better get it right. But others have pointed me toward tools
for doing this.
* http://tinyurl.com/2uyb
* some code from Craig Pardley
* use of ant (but I tried this and couldn't make it work)

. . .

> >QUESTION 3:
> > How do I "turn on" my mock objects when tests are running?
> When faced with testing a constellation of objects that can't easily be
> "installed" with a mock object directly, I try to find ways to do so.
> Sometimes it turns out those objects can be composed in a different
> order like Russian dolls. If that doesn't turn up anything, I'll resort
> to building a factory that plugs in implementations based on a dynamic
> property. I can count the number of times I've done that on one finger.

Interesting. It seems to me like it'd be a much more common
solution than that. I'll go back and look at my designs again
and see if I can come up with a different approach that avoids
the need for the "dynamic property". Perhaps I'm missing a
good solution.

. . .

> As you encounter specific issues not addressed in the FAQ, let us know.
> We'll make it better.

Well, I have one suggestion. In response to my question about
where to place the tests, nearly everybody responded that a
separate source hierarchy was the best place (5 of 6 responders,
and the 6th proposed a new solution and said separate hierarchy
was his second choice). I think that's sufficient agreement to
make this an acknowledged "best practice", and if you agree and
would like to add it to the FAQ, I'll volunteer to write up an
item on it. Let me know.

-- Michael Chermside
